Ted, the check-out guy at the grocery store, was bagging up my items while I drummed on the counter with my hands. “Hey,” he said, glancing around, “You like birds?” I was taken aback; we had never actually spoken before this moment. “Uh, yeah. They’re good, I guess.” “I like ‘em, too. My favorite is the Peregrine. You know that one? It’s this badass falcon. A whole lot of ‘em died in the fifties or something. Now they’re coming back.” “I know them. A pair used to live on my building. One of them died and the other flew off. They’re fast flyers, right?” Perhaps too absolutely, he responded, “They’re the fastest fucking bird there is.” “Oh, really?” The overhead PA garbled something unintelligible. “Yeah. Check out my tat,” he said. Ted untucked his shirttail delicately and raised it to his chin with both hands, glancing once again from side to side. I was not wholly sure if this were appropriate behavior for a cashier on the job. The artwork, however, was truly stunning. Aside from the fact that it was not finished (it was very fresh), there, in a bold outline across his stomach, flew the majestic avian— the definitive, if impartial, Peregrine. “Oh, wow,” I managed to say. Ted nodded eagerly. Then, as if summoned, a small, brooding man appeared behind the register with a clipboard in hand. His name-tag read Tom in large, plain letters. He was obviously Ted’s manager. I pictured a blue Igloo lunchbox in the break room, wherever that was. He leaned over and whispered something to Ted which I couldn’t hear. “The Peregrine, of course,” Ted replied. “You’re absolutely right,” Tom agreed. Ted’s gaze became slightly perplexed and far-off. He peered at me (through me) for a long moment before removing his shirt and exiting the store. “Uh, hey, where’s he going? You didn’t just you fire him, did you?” I asked Tom. Tom did not answer me. His face, too, was now bereft of any former quality. “Hey, snap out of it! What just happened?” “It is our time, it is not their time,” Tom murmured. “What the hell are you talking about?” “Sir, what do you stand for?” “Excuse me?” I was shocked. “I said, what do you stand for?” To this preposterous question I could not think of an answer. No one had ever asked me that before. Once, I thought, I stood for high art, and literature. As for now, having been pressed by a stranger in a strange situation, I simply felt confused and highly self-aware. I rounded up my groceries and quickly left the store. I got the hell away from Tom. A few weeks passed by. I bought my groceries elsewhere and nearly forgot about Ted, Tom, and the Peregrine. One afternoon, I found Ted constructing what looked like a nest on the sixth floor balcony of the tenement across the street. His tattoo, from a distance, appeared to be complete. I called up to him, curious as to what the hell he was up to— what exactly he believed he was doing up there. He squawked at me.

…what do I stand for?

“Between you and me,” I explained, “the man was a louse. Had it been up to him, we would see a turkey on the flag.” “How about, ‘Early to bed and early to rise, makes a man healthy, wealthy, and wise?’” the waitress, Lucy, inquired. “A silly rhyme you tell to children. And do not get me started on his banking system,” I glowered. “You really don’t like him, huh?” “It is not that I care for him or not care for him. I do not believe in his principles.” “Well, I read this one the other day: ‘At twenty years the will reigns, at thirty the wit, at forty the judgment.’ That one’s worthwhile, right?” “I believe I am going to give up on you, Lucy, if you are not careful,” I smiled. “Daylight savings?” “Pencil shavings. Will you bring my coffee, please?” “Yes, coming up, hun.” “Cream, no sugar, please.” And she left. It was a good thing, too. She was a sweet girl, Lucy, though discussion of B. Franklin’s nonsense was an abhorrent waste of time. For my respect, a man must abandon the trappings of organized society and embrace his inner instincts, not quell them with endless quotes. The Founders were regulatory ninnies. "Bah," I exhaled. I turned my attention outward, scratched my bald head. A newspaper hit the window, then stole away into the void. I closed my eyes and began to om. The diner softly dissapated and gave way to visions, or omens. “It’s just that he discovered electricity, remember? With that kite. And the key?” Lucy persisted, coughing first to get my attention. “I do not care if he invented the paper I wipe my ass with. Pardon me. Do not bring him up again, please.” “Alright, alright. Here you go, hun.” The coffee steamed cautiously. “Thank you,” I said cautiously. After a moment I recollected myself, and returned to my mantra. In the clearing of my mind a murder of crows heckled a tiny calico cat. The cat, rearing up on his haunches, hissed furiously, as he was vastly outnumbered. This stance proved he would know no fear, and, briefly, he became a fearsome tiger. His swipe at the largest, and therefore deadliest, crow, disgraced the attackers. They cocked their heads to the side and sat. Shift then to a man wearing a red clown nose, dancing down the sidewalk. He had been beaten and bruised. He had no money. Luck would have him dead, or worse. His mouth was agape in horror, while his eyes were wide with delight. No one noticed, or cared, least of all himself.  He halted and looked directly at me. He did not blink. Lucy's coughing once again pulled me from my meditation. “So what brings you in, hun? You’ve been sitting for hours. Everything alright? You’re dressed really funny.” “I apologize. These are my robes, and I am waiting for a friend, Lucy. We are supposed to meet here.” “Robes? What are you into now?” “Lucy, I am not “into” anything now. I have found my true self and enlightenment through the spiritual teachings of the Buddha. Actualization may be a difficult concept to grasp for those looking outside-in.” “Oh. Well pardon me, Mr. Enlightenment. It is nice to see you happy, or at peace, at least.” “Thank you. It is a never ending struggle, you know,” I resigned with a sigh, and a smile. “Oh, I know, hun. Believe me!” We had a laugh. One day she could find it, too: the calm, and the tempest, and the calm. “Who’re you waiting for? Ted Lowell?” she asked. “No.” “Alfonso?” “Not today.” “Fred, that traveling salesman guy, Fred?” “I do not believe you have met him before, Lucy. He is the Dalai Lama.” “The Dalai Lama…?!” “He looks like the Dalai Lama,” I said. The black star clock read 1:08 in SPACE HOURS.

Even though I arrived nearly fifteen minutes early to the trial, my nerves could not have been more shot. I hadn't slept a wink for three days, first of all. My subpoena was left on the bus, abandoned. I could hardly recall the assailant's profile. My suit wasn't pressed, and my tie was a shambles. There were grass stains on my shirt. I hadn't showered, and my toes stuck together. I wasn't wearing any socks. My hairstyle was beyond reprieve. My eyeballs were barren and itchy. And then, I was practically crying. I detected a parakeet in my stomach, flapping it's wings. "They're ready for you now," the bailiff said. I made my way in. Then, something tugged on my jacket sleeve. It was a little man with a pug nose. He wanted to borrow my telephone. In his right hand he held a brown paper bag scarcely concealing a bottle of Listerine. He lifted it, glanced around before slugging a long pull, and farted. Deep inside me, my heart confided that together we shall inherit the Earth, not to mention it's miseries. "Here you go," I said, handing the midget a cell phone. "...'preciate it," he said. "Just make it quick. I'm needed." I said. He held the phone upside down and asked loudly to not to speak to a secretary, not this time. His shouting frightened lawyers passing by. ...ambition is a veiled bride at her wake; a midget tip-toeing in some vichy ballroom; erstwhile children orate bloody wide-eyed tales in immeasurable years following a war.

The sound of these thoughts titillated my mind. Perhaps I should settle down and write a book. "Ahem," the bailiff said. The jury downed a glass of water.

A few Jehovah witness men came to my door. Abby was glib.
"Let   me tell you something about the watchtower! It's deserted! No one on   high! Take your pamphlets and you can shove them!" she hollered.
"Thanks, guys. Not today," I said.
"Blessed be those who give themselves-"
I closed the door and went back to the 3D puzzle I was working on: the statues of Easter isle.
"Those   guys seriously need to re-evaluate their lives. Seriously," Abby said   from the hall. She was dusting the trim, over and over.
"Gotta make a living somehow," I said.
"You make three dollars a day selling bean bags, tootsie pop."
"All for you, coffee cake."
There was a knock at the door. This time it was our neighbor, wearing drab rubber river waders. Rain pat-patted on his cap.
"Your dog is in my yard again," he said.
"Hanz, we don't have a dog, remember?" I said.
"None of that tripe, boy. Get that damn pyrenees out of my yard or I'll throw it in the chipper." 
I shut the door as he finished laughing. Once, he caught my boat on fire just to spite me. He was a terrible old fart.
"Stay dry out there, Hanz," I said.
"I miss Spike," Abby said. 
"Me too, pistachio." 
Spike was our pyrenees puppy.
"No you don't! All you do is drink all day! I can't take this anymore!" she sobbed. 
Another knock at the door. It was the police.
"Sir,   there have been complaints of strange bouts of depression emanating   from this residence. Permit me to look around?" said Officer Krab.
I   swung the door wide and allowed them in. We had not entertained company   in years. One of the officers started squinting. Admittedly, the place  was a  little worse for the wear. The sofas were upside down. Mice ran   unabashedly.
"This is Abby," I said.
Abby sat inside a ring of kleenex on the floor. Officer Krab took some notes. 
"...never seen this before," he murmured.
I   lead them downstairs to the torture chamber. They examined the   stockade, the iron maiden, guillotine, my various whips, chains, and   flails. The female officer, Stubblefield, shined her badge to the man   in the rack. He was unconscious. 
"I have a license for that," I said.
"We'll have a look at that upstairs," Krab said.
 Back in the kitchen, Abby began peeling off the wallpaper with her fingernails. 
"I was penetrated by a filthy magistrate!" she proclaimed.

Though we started our trek on virtually a whim, Larry and I had been clambering an unnamed trail deep in the vast wilderness for roughly two weeks now. To say the hike was a scenic one would be an understatement; on the first day, our path wound through misty waterfalls and across cliff faces; by day six, it was as if we were on a different continent altogether. The looming Douglas Firs had dispersed, the sword ferns had retreated, whle deep crevasses in the Earth gently healed themselves, inviting petite acai and gumwood trees to inhabit the low, golden hills of this: our new land. The occasional breeze was sweet and warm and lulling. Ahead of me, Larry halted, his arm raised in a fist.
"I think we should wait for some clouds to form to catch our bearings," he said. "That sounds good to me," I said.
I began to unpack. There was little left of my rations. Larry had been out since morning, though neither of us worried much. What we found here would be ours. "Do you know about the ancient civilization out here?" he said. I looked around, but there was nothing there.
"Not particularly," I said. "Somewhere nearby is a cove where the sunlight never shines, or so I've heard. There is some kind of village aside the cove. Huts are made from moss and river rocks, with cold water running through the foundations. The natives are said communicate with their hands, eyes, and feet." "What do you think they eat? For food?" "It's tough to say. They fear agriculture,"  he said. "Of course," I said. "They fear the future." For a brief moment I imagined some secret ruins in the foliage. My eyes squinted to see. A totem seemed to appear and vanish, though I couldn't be sure it was actual. Later, a macaw landed on my shoulder. I fed it some granola, and it flew away. I wondered how old it was. "We could probably conquer them," Larry said. "Huh?" "I said we should conquer them, the villagers." "What if they know we're coming? I'd like to see my family again, Larry. You're scaring me a little." "They'll have no idea, these tribal dolts. I'll approach them from the south, you come around, later, from the east. We'll flank them in a pincer strike. There is nothing to worry about." "We don't even know where to find this village, let alone whether or not it exists. It could be anywhere." Slowly, Larry touched the ground, and delicately tasted his fingers. He pointed to our left. "It's that way," he said. "Don't ask why, something just calls to me. Like a voice."
"I don't like this, Larry."
"I don't give a shit what you like." A tiger snarled behind us. I was suddenly and inexplicably terrified, not only of Larry, but also my inability to stop him. "Suppose we come across a shaman or something? What if my teeth get turned into grapes? I don't want my teeth turned into grapes, Larry," I said. "Shut your fucking flap and wrap these vines around your body. And here, take this machete," he said. I wasn't aware we brought a machete. Where had he...? "What if there is no village?" I asked faintly. "Then, my friend, we hunt for the Madonna, Mother of hope, tears of blood," he said. I nodded. "We attack at twilight," he said. He disappeared into a cropping of black orchids. Across the sun flew a great egret of silver, blue and scarlet. I just kept standing there, looking around.

Just fifteen minutes until closing time, and all I can comprehend are giant dirigibles and old fashioned flying machines. There I am, weightless, goggles on, performing loop-de-loops as my children watch from the ground below. Kids are amazed by anything! I land choppily and give my son the scarf my own father had untrusted me. It's when I wrap it around his neck that I realize just how big he has gotten. Our compatriot Wilbur zooms by on a velocipede. Leagues of sunny maritimers pursue him down the boardwalk. Life is good by the sea, in the air. Wilbur comes back to us and says, "Here, you'll want this." He removes his head and tosses it to my daughter. Wilbur is, in fact, an automaton. Little Mavis squeels with gaiety at her new antiquated face. "I'll oil you every day!" she says. "And brush your tin hair and we'll play jacks and marbles and share our secrets...though you mustn't tell anyone!" Wilbur is delighted. He says, "Let us embark for the city of tomorrow."
"Excuse me, sir? Can you validate my parking?" a woman says.
"Why, of course. That is no problem. Do you worship God, or gods?" I ask.
"Neitzsche is a faggot. God is Alive," she says. There are bits of stained glass in her hair. 
I swoop a ticket into her hand, a pterodactyl returning to feed her baby dinosaurs.
"Can you even begin to understand His majesty?" she asks.
I call for the manager.

Old Marvin was obviously blind. We all knew it. Everyday he would come into the bank to check his balance and take about five minutes just feeling around as though he had never seen anything before. He'd pass the plants, the fake ones in the lobby, and he'd always say, "oh, heavens," as he batted their dust-covered plastic fronds. It was sort of funny, in its way, though we never called him out because was so kindly, and he didn't wear glasses or carry a cane. Plus, he wasn't that old. We didn't want to embarrass him. One afternoon he bumped into another man on his path to a teller. The man was cordial about it, even though Marvin dislodged his toupee which subsequently fell into a soapy water bucket that the janitor was using. Marvin just apologized and continued on, staring at nothing in particular. Jennica told me later that Marvin was pulling out a loan for a car. 
"Is he good for it? I mean, can we do it?" I asked.
"Yeah, it all checks with his credit."
"Did you clear him?"
"Well, what was I supposed to do?"
Neither of us spoke for the rest of the day, after that. I quit later that week, due to a pay-cut. I went outside for some fresh air just as a new tire rolled by intrepidly.

As always, our little group convened again on Wednesday. Even in spite of last week's fiasco, there we were, sitting, laughing, interrogating like old chums, sipping our coffees (Julie with a sweet chai). Margo told us that she had picked up another book on star-gazing just the other day. She had already dog-eared several pages, we were assured.
"Can you show us where to find Ursa major?" Alan asked.
"On a clear night, yes," Margo beamed.
"How about minor?" Julie piped in, slyly.
"Sure. Though that one's a little tougher."
"I can only imagine," I laughed, astonished.
Margo really knew her stuff when it came to the cosmos- assuming she was telling the truth.
Later, when the time was right, Alan thought it appropriate to discuss his wife with us. On Sunday Juliette would be five years dead.
"I remember when we used to ride up to Devil's Mountain in my old pick-up. You could see for miles. All the towns and hills. At night especially when all you could see were dots in the sky...on the land. I just miss her so much."
It was difficult. We had all known her, and loved her. Her smiles, though rare, were bright as sunshine through cotton particles in Tennessee. She was tiny, stylish; an occasionally eccentric woman whose baking skills found ovation in even the most highfalutin critic. Her wasp(!) honey glazed croissants still captivated us all. My mouth watered bittersweet. Alan slunk over and became melancholy, a prisoner of her alive and thriving memory. We all took our turns hugging him and letting him know that it was going to be alright. I was last and told him that she was irreplaceable, a real ruby in the sand.
"We all miss her, buddy."
He nodded, dodging our concerned faces. Margo and Julie's quiet conversation to each other grew louder, though I wasn't really listening and neither was Alan.
"...so many women who would be so lucky..." was heard, however, and Alan grinned, red-in-the-face. I patted him on the back. 
Simultaneously, two candy bars fell right out of my pocket.
A silence fell behind them.
"Kit-Kats? Give me a break!" Julie's voice trilled, finally. Alan chuckled.
Since I began dieting months ago I knew I had to forbid myself from most sugars: sucrose, lactose, glucose, high fructose corn syrup (at least whenever possible) in order to lose weight and feel good about myself again. In total, I had lost one hundred pounds. Everyone had been incredibly supportive of my decision in this, Julie most of all. Julie was a recovering alcoholic and knew well the importance of self-control.
"It's not what it looks like. I'm just holding them for a friend. Or something."
"I think it's exactly what it looks like," Alan muttered, amused.
"Who, pray tell, are you 'holding' them for?" Margo sighed.
I was going to catch flack for this, for appearing weak. These people were born for flack, though. I figured I'd just try to play coy and have some fun.
"Well, last night I..."
"Went on a binge? Fell off the wagon? How many more were there? I can't believe this. Christ's sake why are you so weak?" Julie would be relentless. I feared her eyes, actually.
"No, last night I went out with a lady. I know, it must be hard to believe, but I had a date. We went to a movie and she must have slid these in my pocket. That's all."
"Which theater? The Blue Moon? Downtown?" Julie persisted.
I nodded, sort of shrugged.
"Nuh-uh. Nice try. They don't sell Kit-Kats at that theater. Also, I was there last night as well and I didn't see you."
"Huh. Is that so?"
"C'mon, Jules. Guy deserves a little treat here and there," Alan said.
"You stay out of this one, Steinman!" Julie barked playfully.
"Fine. You got me. And you were going to find out anyway, you know. I picked them up for myself and for all of us. No, really. I'm serious Julie! There are four to a pack and there are four of us. That is two apiece. I think that's fair. Today marks one hundred pounds lost."
All eyebrows raised high in some emotion. Smiles spread more slowly.
"I was excited," I finished. "Don't look at me like that."
"I'm going to call the police!" Julie exclaimed. Her manner in the group was cynical, often accusatory. In truth, her eyes would be the first to congratulate. She had always been there for me, even before the divorce. Her faith ran deep.
She also had a knack for elusiveness.  
"Well, I think that that's just wonderful. To remember how nice a reward can be. Yes. Well done! I'll take mine now, thank you," Margo tweeted, smokily.
"Yeah I'll have one of those. Keep it up, bud. You're doing great," Alan offered, smiling. I thanked him.
As Julie picked the chocolate bars from the ground and removed their wrappers, I wondered if she had any idea how much she meant to me. Would she, my Juliette, eating her unbroken Kit-Kat's, someday depart my dreams? Could these friends break apart? Our wistful sinfonia dissipated into overtones? We are the orchestral players.
"Don't you dare do this again, though," Julie leads with cello.
"I would never," my tympani concludes.

The earth trembles each day with no notice, and here you are stomping your foot and begging me for a difference. Some goddamn difference. I stare across the floor, thinking. It's difficult to spot a happening when one doesn't know what's been altered in the first place. I'm miserable. There are these people all lined up at the bar, drinking. They've got scotch tapes on their faces where shapes make out odd yellow flickering frenzy. Ale froth gone tepid stained on smiles. A man wheezes at the lonely joke his brother murdered, falling off his stool. He writhes over to me and jabs about crippled feet and melting designs in architecture he learned about in his school days, then says, "what bout you bub where you learn at?" unaware of how death his breath makes somber. I reply, "i didn't. it's just tough for us nowadays, anyhow." Nothing resembles belated memories. There was never any school for me, he must have known that. That's what you knew so well. You made sure to make a point of it. I say, "i need to go," and think back to you and of the time we lay under those red bedsheets, devising secret plans, when to our surprise an army of ants marched right out of your mouth and poured over our vigor. You screamed- presently from this man I excuse myself so as to wash up in the far back bar bathroom, nervous of all things, nervous of ants! You wouldn't stop screaming- I can't catch my bearings in the grimy stall; it's slippery; I can't locate any focus. I flush though there's nothing there and my mirror-double is stymied with guilt and defeat, horror and acne, and I confess that he is like you in that he demands in ribald candor for me to deliver these dreams upon sponges the way I see it. Leave me alone, for once. I can't even live, barely! My only visions are the undersides of faces, chipped in immeasurable granite, swarming with locusts.

"I asked for Snapple Regular!" raged the boss, hurling the bottle of Snapple Flavor that caught me hard right below my left ear. The pain shot through me and mixed devilishly with my failure. I started bawling. "Get it right or I'll fire you!" he continued, pounding his fists. From his fury I stumbled out onto the hallway floor, a crying mess. Thankfully, no one seemed to notice me collapse except for Anne, who I don't like. "Why don't you just go take a nap, Manne," I sobbed. She glared at me but I flipped her off. What is with this company? I thought. I had a bad headache in the back of my skull. Maybe it was from everyone being so damn disappointed in me all the time. Anne kept glaring at me. I just couldn't handle it any longer. Something snapped in me and suddenly all I wanted to do was stand up for myself. After a quick inhale I shot back to the office to blow some steam into the boss' milk. "Uh, Chief?" I said, knocking on his door and trying my absolute hardest not to cry, "I'm not sure what you think I'm supposed to do around here, but really, truly, I've been to every Snapple Store in this city, and they stopped making Snapple Regular five years ago. I just can't find it. Sir." To avoid his gaze I tiptoed around the room, in search of something, anything. I settled on some pictures hanging against the far wall. They were difficult to see thoroughly with my vision being so watered, though it was easy enough to discern their subject. I had never known the boss to be a fan of anything, much less figure skating, but there he was clear as ice, pulling off the perfect triple axle. He looked fabulous in his white spandex uni and rhinestones, really. "I originally hired you under the pretense that you would accomplish any task I should require of you. So what you are telling me here is that you have given up on the job I hired you specifically for," he said. I cleared my throat, "Ahem, uh, well, sir, when you put it in that context, then yes, I suppose you could say that. But you must know that I have been searching and searching since before nine this morning, and when I ask all the clerks and the cashiers if they carry this drink they shake their heads and tell me not to ask about it anymore. 'Snapple Flavor, only,' they say, then they point to this poster that reads: uh, 'Here at Snapple we recognize thirst, and our first priority is to burst Flavor into every bottle. Snapple Flavor! Don't be Regular anymore!' and there is a picture of this guy on a boat with yellow tinted glasses holding a bottle of Flavor, and he's surrounded by, this kind of psychedelic swirly thing, which is cool, and pretty. Why don't you drink that, sir? It's delicious, really. I mean judging by your, uh, vibrant lifestyle, it seems like you would love it," I finished, hoping that he didn't take that last as sarcasm. It wasn't meant to be sarcasm. Carefully, I placed the bottle back in front of him, and ran to the space between the open door and the wall, still sniffling, but not that much.  For a moment I was certain he was going to explode. However, to my surprise, I could hear him breathing calmly, if loudly. I poked my head out and he was somehow standing gentile, staring at the photos on the wall as if remembering a friend long gone. Did he notice me staring at them? I wondered. He took one down and held it out towards me. I reached for it timidly. As he spoke I noticed something in his voice had changed, "I had passion, once, you know? I breathed passion. I sweat passion," he rubbed his temples as I took the photo, "I would slice through ice to roars of millions. Deafening, yes, but if you could only know the sheer enthusiasm. The fires of the masses, melting the ground beneath me, trembling. They would have me glide and I would have them weeping. Weeping from deep down, from that place where great beauty resides. And then, I was that beauty. What I am saying is, I have drank that drink, that Flavor. They were the regulars! The people, ha. That drink was my life! It encompassed me, filled me with warmth. But now look. Look at the price I have paid. That same beauty has sucked itself dry and been with replaced with schedules and meetings and taxes and wristwatches. The beauty is gone and all that is left is myself, a Regular. How can I fool myself any longer? I cannot. It is too late for me, son. You have shown me that." He idled to the fainting sofa in the corner. He pulled a fuzzy blanket over his thin frame. The room became cold. I couldn't help but rush to his side, and he looked very weak. "No! No it's not gone, don't you blame me for this!" I cried, "All you need to do is drink! There's still beauty in there, I can see it, sir!" He didn't seem to hear me. His eyes were pale, a vacant slate tumbling downward. His breath came short, "You are relieved of your task, boy. I know now, you tried for this old man, moreso than anyone I have ever met. I am sorry for being so coarse with you. Remember me. Tell Snapple to bring Regular back. For us old guys," as he perished. A warm blue light filled my heart, though only lasted for a brief moment.
